div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER."

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature's Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.

div.head: EUROPE AND ISLAM.
div.p: The "Tribune" says "The first day of the new year has witnessed the solemn ratification at Madrid of the Act which closed the Conference at Aigeciras. The Moroccan affair has entered at last upon an interesting phase, but it is the Moors, and not tho diplomatists, who supply the dramatic element. The decision of the French and Spanish Governments to send a naval expedition to Tangier caused some misgiving among prudent men in Paris, which, we confess, we shared, though we saw no alternative to the very loyal and limited plan of intervention which M. Pichon had drawn up. Of course, the fleets would have no ditficulty in disposing of Raisuli, but Raisuli, brigand though he was, seemed to be the ope strong man and thé one popular leader in Morocco. What would happen if the only vigorous element in the rotten Moroccan society were destroyed, and how would Europeans fare in the end if a great movement of fanaticism should bo excited 1 These were the questions which M. Jaurès askod. The event has proved how accurately M. Pichon, who came from the Residency at Tunis to guide the French Foreign Office, knows his North Africa. For the appearance of the fleets had actually tho result of galvanising tho Moorish Government into a show of energy. An army was got together, and even paid. It marched

slowly to Tangier, and, once arrived there, it displayed its shabby pomp without so much as an attempt at resistance. Raisuli was deposed and declared a rebel, and his lieutenant, at whose word all Tangier had trembled, quietly followed the Sultan's General to the iposque and made his public submission. Raisuli, to be sure, is issuing proclamations from his mountain fastness, but his power is gone, and we must reckon him among the typical picturesque brigands of the East whose authority rests on a legend which one day of inaction and hesitation may destroy. Whatever the ezplanation may be—and it is quite possible that the Sultan and Raisuli are secretly acting in collusion—two satisfactory conclusions seem airly safe. In the first place, the Moore know that it is folly to challenge the armed intervention of Europe, and unless they have some Power to back them they cannot resist reform. In the seoond place, it is fairly obvious that evep in Morocco, the most backward of all Mohamedan lknds, fanaticism is no longer a force which can be trusted to resist the march of European civilisation.

"The tame development of this Moroccan incident,' the willingness of the Sultan to depose a powerful personality who happened to be obnoxious to Europeans, and, above all, the complete quiet of the native population while those things happened under the guns of infidel warships, make the recent talk about a fanatical revival of Islam throughout the world seem exceedingly foolish. If half this imaginative and alarmist gossip had been true, the sailing of the Franco-Spamah squadron ought to have caused a ferment all over the Mohamedan world ; the Senousai brotherhood should long since have been leading a Jehad, while France in Algeria and England in Egypt should have been feeling by now the consequences of that solidarity which is supposed to link all Islam against all Christendom. None of these things have happened, and the reason is simply that the revival, which is happily a reality among several Mohamedan peoples, is not a concerted movement, and still less is it a fanatical movement. In Egypt there is unquestionably a Nationalist movement among a population which happens to be Mohamedan, and its aim todemand self-government (if we follow its more moderate exponents) or to ask for the fulfilment of Mr. Gladstone's pledges çf withdrawal (if we follow its more ardent spirits). How utterly different the movement in India isa telegram which we print to-day reminds us. rhero a League of Moslems haa been formed, which desires to further education and to offer a certain conservative opposition to the radical Hindu element. Its programme makes it absolutely clear that this league will be a loyalist oody, bent on balancing the Bengali agitation by an altitude of absolute defereooe to English rule. lu Persia a curious constitutional movement, which seems to have in it some elements of hope and progress, is making its power felt, „but it can have no possible link with the parties in Egypt and in India, for the simple reason that the Persians are heretics, almost os obnoxious as infidels to the orthodox Sunni Moslemsof theWeat. In Russia, again, the re is also a certain ferment, aqd it is frankly liberal, and allied itself politically with the Constitutional Democrats in tho late Duma There is no sign of concerted action, nothing anti- Christian in any of those movements, and certainly nothing fanatical. Three out of four are avowedly liberal and democratic, and all are deeply interested in education. So far as they have a religious basis at all,it is a liberalising and a humane tendency. It is opposed to the old brotherhoods, which really did excite fanaticism and perpetuate ignorance. It works for a freer interpretation of the Koran, aqd it is facing on ita own Mohamedan basis the very same difficulties in the rooonoiliation of religion and science with which Christians have so long been wrestling—as indeed Prof. Vamb ry has explained in his 'Western Culture in Eastern Lands.' It is, in short, a movement which, seeks to make terms with the now learning which is invading the East, to preserve Islam by reforming it, and to purge it of the old elements which make for isolation, stagnation, and fanaticism."

div.p: A policeman attempted breaking into Messrs. Tabit's grocery stores at Khartoum the other night. div.head:
LONDON TO ALEXANDRIA IN 87 HOURS.
EGYPTIAN STEAMSHIP COMPANY.
div.p: LONDON, Friday.

We are within measurable distance of the time when it will be possible to travel from London to Alexandria in 87 hours, and this by the flotation of the Egyptian Mail Steamship Company, Limited, with a capital of £660,000, divided into 60,000 Ordinary shares of £10 eaoh and 60,000 Deferred-shares of £1 each. We understand that the capital has already been largely seoured and that only £200,000 will be offered to the publia The establishment ot the company promises to revolutionise the Steepler service between Marseilles and Alexandria. The company's steamers w'll reproduce all the most striking features of the newest AtlaDtio liners, and as regards comfort and speed will surpass anything hitherto attempted by any lines running between Europe and Egypt T hey will be fitted with turbines developing a Bpeed of not less than 20} knots an boor, at whioh speed the passage between Marseilles and Alexandria bhould be accomplished in 70 boars. The 8 tea mers are to be ready in October next.

div.head:
CAIRO "ZOO."
SOME IMPORTANT ADDITIONS.
div.p: The Director of the Zoological Gardens, who returned from the Sudan on tbe 25th Deoem her, 1906, brought the following live Sudanese animals to Cairo :—
1.—One very fine young .male giraffe, giraffa Camelopardalis, from Kordofan, a particularly riohly marked animal.

list.item: 2.-Three young African elephants, two males and one female, from the Blue Nile. Ooe of the males has small tusks, the otberls still quite a baby elephant. These, together with the three female elephants brought from the Blue Nile in 1905, now form a fine group of six Afrioan elephants, a feature probably never seen before in any zoological gardens. These six éléphants, answering to the names of "Teddy," ' Jombo," "Alice," "Deesa," 'Dinder," and ' Karkoj," are exeroised together in the gardens in the afternoon, and no visitor to Egypt shoold miss seeing this unique sight

3.—Two female wild dookeys, equus asinus africanus. Ooe from the province of Berber presented by Msjor Sir Henry Hill, Bart, Royal Irish Fudliers ; and one from Goz Regeb, on the Atbara, presented by Mr. A. N, Wilkinson, Inspector, Repression of Slave Trade.
4.—One male sabre horned antelope, Oryx lenooryx, from Kordofan.
5.—Five ( two male and three female ) individuals of the rare and beautiful Ril antelope, gasella rufioollis, from Kordofan.
6.—A young pair of Korin gazelles, gasella rufifiroDP, from Kawa, White Nile, presented by Mr. Robert Langslow, Publie Works Department.
7.—A yonog male northern waterbook, oobus defassa, from Roseires, Blue Nile, pre sented by Mr. L. Gorringe, Inspector, Repression of Slave Trade.
8.—A pair of Abyssipian bushbuok, tra- gelaphus deoula, (new to the oolleotion), from Roseires, presented by Mr. L Gorringe.
9.—One male oribi, ourebia moqtana, from Roseires, presented by Mr. L Gorringe.
10.—On© female Doguera baboon, papio anubisvar. inoert., frein tbe Bahr el Ghazal, presented by H. B. el Leva C. D. Hanter Pasha, D 8.Q., R.A.M-C.
12.—Two red b^okéd sparrows, passer rnfi- dorsalis, from Khartoum,

div.p: 13.—One Cretgscbmar's bunting, emheriza Oaesia, from Khartoum.
14. —Ouegrey heron, ardea cinerea, from Khar ton it, presented by Mr. A. L Bp tier, F.Z.8, M.B.O.U., Superintendant, Game Preservation Department, Sudan.
15. One roseygrey dove, tnrtor roseq- griseoa, from near Wad Medani, Blue Nile. This beautiful dove, first fiesoribed by Sunde- vall in lff5f, has not been previonsly exhibited in the Ghizeh Gardens.

list.item: 16.—Two leopard tortoises, testado par- dalis, from the Vpper Nile.
17.—Two spurred tqrtoiwe, teetpdo ©al- carata, from Kordofau.

div.head:
MUSTAPHA'S FRIENDS.
SEIFULLAH PAGHA YUSRI,
div.p: A vigorous and good-looking young man, isually believed to bave nothing to expeot from his good looks, for men who really ooont require brains. But the public was wrong. Saifullah's Pasha's gifts have been of inoredible use to him. They bave made h'm a kinsman of prinoes, not to say kiogs, and he is now the suooeasor of Jamil Pasha Sabet and Prinoe Fuad. As for his peouniary gains, we need not mention them. We do not propose to explain how he aeqaired his wife's fortune and properties. That is a private affair

Bat he has gained a great moral advantage from his marriage with a charming, virtuous, and talented prinoess, and his association with her can only be to his advantage. His new relationship ought to make of him a high minded idealist and remove him from all that can sully » character. Ha has beoome riob and remarkable. Hence it is not surprising to see his name on the list.

div.head: EGYPTIAN COTTON IN AMERICA
div.p: Pawtucket, R I.—Cotton yarn mannfaotu rere in this city are said to have invested quite largely in Egyptian ootton, because of a scarcity of long staple domestio ootton. The Egyptian product iB said to be needed in order to keep up the standard of yarn tarred out of some of the yarn mills. Farther then to say that Egyptian ootton is beiog used, the yarn manufacturers will not disooss the matter. Nearly all of them bave been using some Egyptian ootton all along. It is stated on what is considered excellent antboiity that the aggregate pnrobase of Egyptian ootton by Pawtnoket manof»otoreT8 amounts to a good deal. It is said also that they bought to advantage. Their porch aies were made several weeks ago. High grade Egyptian ootton is now soling at 33 } to 34 oents a pound, whereas two mouth-r ago it ooold be had at 22 } oents. Inquiry at two of the most im portaut ootton brokerage i ffi ies in Providence | brought out the fjot that the Egyptian ootton was not puroh-tse 1 through those offices and that it is thought the rumoured pnroha res were made through Boston offioes. The Egyptian prodoot is bring substituted mostly for Sea Island ootton, of v^hioh there is a great - in U»e market

div.head:
KHEDIVIAL STEAMSHIP COMPANY.
INCREASE OF CAPITAL.
div.p: An extraordinary general meeting of the Khédivial Mail 8t9amsbip and Graving Dock Company (Limited) was held at Winchester House, Old Broad street London, RO., on December 81, Sir Auckland Colvin, K.C.S.I., K.C.M.G, presiding. The attendance of share holders was verymeagro.
The Seoretary (Mr. L. Halliday) having read the notice convening the meeting,
The Chairman formally proposed that the resolution altering the Artioles of Association of the company, which was passed at an extraordinary general meeting held on Deo.
14 last, be confirmed as a special resolution.
Mr. P. Allen seconded, and the motion was agreed to.
A second extraordinary general meeting was then held for the purpose of considering and passing the following resolution : —

"That the capital of the company be increased to 400,000/. by the creation of 100,000 new ordinary shares of 1/. each, ranking in all reapeota on an iquality with the existing ordinary shares, and that in lieu of such new shares being offered in the manner provided by Article 13 of the company's artioles of association the direotors be and are hereby authorised and empowered to issue the said new shares upon auoh terms as to price, and on suoh conditions as to underwriting, and otherwise, and at each times, and generally in 8ooh manner as they may deem expedient, and whether in the form of bearer shares, or registered shares, or partly in one form and partly in the other, provided always that the direotors shall give a preferential allotment of snoh new shares to tho holders of ordinary and preference shares of the company in proportion to their respective holdings."
The Seoretary having read the notice convening the meeting, and also the above resolution,

The Chairman said : The articles of association having been altered by the resolution reoently submitted, it is now competent for the company to increase its capita1. Before any steps oan, however, be taken in that direotion it is neoessary that the resolution which is about to be submitted to you for approval should be passed by you ; and, in ord?r that you may understand the objeota which yoar board have in view in asking yon to approve the resolution, a few words from me are required which will plaes you in possession of the situation as it presents itself to yonr direotors. Mainly owing to the growth of the company's business the strength of its fhet is scarcely adequate to discharge the oalls that are made upon it, more especially daring the bnsy season of the year. We have reoently, as yoa are aware, enlarged the sphere of our operations by the establishment of a line from 8uez to Port Sudan. You are, again, aware that we have always bad in view the gradaal replacement of suoh of our fleet taken over by us in 1898 from the Egyptian Governmentasmightbeoome,from age or other oause, unsuitable to our service. Whether, therefore, in regard to the strength or the oapaoity of our fleet, we believe that in the present condition of our affairs we should be well advised to obtain, under the favourable terms which we may reasonably expeot, the further oapital needed to eoable us to serve both the objects whioh I have enumerated. You will not expeot or wish me to indloate preoisely at pfoseut the tonnage of the new Bhlps we propose to acquire. That must be settled by the board on ex haustive consideration ot tbeir respoosibilities and their means of meeting them. It will be enough to add that the proposed issue will, if Deoessary, plaoe the board in possession of sufficient means to meet the requirements which 1 have indicated to you, and that the acquirement of a better olasa of boat will be aooompanied by corresponding profits, owing to their greater oarrying power, capaoity, and popularity when compared with the boats present in use. The direotors, after very earefally considering the requirements of the business and the prwpeots of trade, have come to the conclusion that it is desirable to atilise the greater part of suoh sum as may be raised by the iwne of the proposed 100,000 new shares, so as to provide for the require meats which I have just indicated. Your board pannot at present say whether it may prove desirable to make arrangements to ensure the suooess of the issue by underwriting it. This, if needfal, will be done upon the best terms available. With regard to the price at which the new shares are to be issued, the direotors are taking into aooonnt the speoial oiroumstau- oes in connection with the, position of the company and the augmentation of oapital proposed. Under the provisions of the resolution to be submitted to you, they will fix the pre mium and other conditions in the best interrstp, as they believe, of the shareholders. Whatever oourse may be adopted, you will see by the terms of the resolution that it is proposed by the board in the first instauoe to give the ordinary and preference shareholders of the company priority of allotment, with the result that suoh shareholders, whether bearer-warrant holders or registered shareholders, will be entitled an allotment of the new oapital in proportion to their existing holdings in the company, In the event of bearer warrant holders desiring to apply for allotments of the new shares, it will be neoessary for them to lodge their warrants at banka to be indicated hereafter,-at Alexandria and in London, previous to the allotment taking pleee. \ now move that the resolution, as read to you, be adopted and oat- riftd.
Mr. J. Temperlay teoonded.
Tbe resolution having been caraied unanimously,
The proceeding! terminated..

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: We are asked to state that Lady Cromer will not be ' at home" at the British Agenoy tomorrow afternoon.
The Bishop of Madras (Dr. Whitehead) has left England for Bgypt, where he wi'l rest tor a mouth, before returning to his diooese.
Sir Thomas Wrighteon has also left Bgypt.
Sir Robert Dasbwood bas left WestWyeombe Park with Dr. Northcote for Egypt.
Sir John Heron Maxwell, a direotor of the Egyptian Estates, Limited, is expected in Cairo shortly.

Sir Charles Wyodham, the popular aotor, and Miss Mary Moore, the equally popular aotress, are ezpeoted to arrive in Cairo next Monday, and after a short stay in the oapita will make a trip up the Nile onder the auspices of Messrs. Cook.
Bishop Ridley will preach at All Saints,' Cairo, on the morning ofSanday, 13th inst.
We regret to hear that Dean Butcher, whose health haB caused considerable anxiety to his many friends in Cairo, passed a very restless tight and shows no signs ot improvement.
In conseqaence of the illness of Dean Batcher, Mrs. Batcher will not be "at home" on Saturday, the 12th inst., nor on any Saturday until farther notice.
Tbe title of Kaimakam has been conferred by H.H. the Khedive on Khalil Bey Hamdi.
Mustapha Pasha Kamel is expeoted to arrive here on the 18uh inst on his return from Europe; accompanied by his friend Mohamed Farid bey.
M. Demetrius Bouboulis, Khédivial Counsallor, is leaving for London, and returns to Cairo at the end of a month.
M. Nioolaon G. Theotoko, son of the Hellenic Premier, is staying at tbs Khédivial Hotel, Alexandria. He leaves shortly for England, to take op his daties at the Hellenio. Legation in London.
Mme Bmelie Sursook, of Beyroot, has arrived in Cairo, where she will spend several weeks.
M. Lonis Bertran, who is travelling for the Revue des Deax Mondes," has arrived at Jerusalem.
Major P. Evans, R.AM.C., nqs been granted month's leave of absence.

Lieut KA.H. James, RE, has been granted sick, leave on the recommendation of a medical board until May 10. He will embark at Port Said to-day on the Japanese Steamship Company's S 3. Inaba Mara for passage to Marseilles, travelling thence to Eugladd overland.

Tbe marriage of Mr. Chas. Baehler to Miss Augusta Flood will take place on the 17th inst. Tbe wedding ceremony, which will be held at Villa Red Court, Ghezireh, will be of the quietest description on aooount of a recent bereavement.

We regret to annouuoe the death of Mr. B. B. G. Porter, manager ot tho Anglo Amerioan Nile Steamship Company's works at Boulao, which ooourred at Cairo yesterday. Deoeased succumbed to a severe illness at the Anglo- American Hospital. We tender our sinoere condolences to the widow and family.

The passengers by the train de luxe for Upper Egypt last night were: Ciunt and Countess Isnaroes, Mr. Pjlotooff, Mr. Damly, Mr. Williamson, Mr. Urquhart, Mr. Herbert, Mr. and Mrs. Vremain, Mlle de With, Mrs. Lina Heyman, Mr. Malsow, Miss Littauer, Mr. Kelekian, Mr. Lindman, Sir. J. Eardly, Mme le Gouida de Pealon, Mr. Cassotti, Mr. Bengovioh.

Colonel Andrioff, chief of the police in Lodz, was shot dead in the street to-day. A patrol fired a volley wounding passers-by, but the assassin escaped. t ' Qeneral Pavloff s/nnrderer has been tried by court-martial,and will be hauged to-night {R.)

div.head: OUR POET'S CORNER.
CLEOPATRA.
div.p: 1 stood by Luxor'* temple, in ita ruin mighty still,
And 1 watched the glow of (.unset out beyond the Libyan hilL
Much I muted on Egypt's story, when it seemed a murmur came
From an ear like aofteet music : 'twaa the utterance of a name—
"Cleopatra, Ah my loved one," thus the wondrous whisper jan ;
And I turned-to see who breathed i^—was it spirit, was he man ?
Nay, he seemed an earthly presence, lithe of limb and keen of eye ;
And hemlf, the Queen of Beauty—yoa, herself was standing by,
Lus trous-or bed and talland stately, and I held my breath to heat —
"Cleopatra, Ah my loved one," came again upon my ear—
"Lo, thaae people are thy poople—this the country* of . . thy birth—
"This thy ri»#r, royal mistress—this dry dust thy nativ* earth.
"On the morrow we will wander whpre entombed the old kings lie ;
"There tç real awhile and ponder on their greatness— thou and I.
'Thou shalllead and I will follow—together we will go;
'For thou know'st each bill and hollow—every desert- path dost know,
*1 will spread a feast before thoe, and, sitting at thy
feat,
"I will gase upon thy beauty, and will watch thee drink and eat.
"I will soothe thee and caress thee, last of Egypt's royal Ha* ;
- "For, as long as I posse»* thee, wealth and power and love are min#,''
Was it Antony the Roman who thus spoke by Luxor's wall— *
Cssaar's friend and Brutus' foeman ? No, it wasn't "Msaat^L
It wa« Abound, number sixty—You might call him
And he owned the Reeteet donkey from Port Said to AasouaiL
G. F. SAMS.
Luxor, 9th January.

div.head: MONUMENT TO ALEXANDER THE GREAT.
APPEAL id HELLENES.
div.p: To the Editor of the Egyptian Gazbttb.

Sir,—There has been of late a movement among several of oar leading Hellenio citizens to erect a monument to the illustrions herb who founded this oity in B.C. 323. The fbrm that this monument should take is that of an imposing Btatue of the great Macedonian warrior ; and no better site could be choien for a pe lestai than the Isle of Pharos, on which he conoeived the idea of' foonding 'what was henceforth to be a world-oentre.

Thereis a very interesting tradition toldabont this founding of Alexandria, and although few people have faith in superstition, the pfo pheoy which thia tradition embodied bps been so fally realised as to merit notice For want of ch die, the soil being black, so runs the legend, floor was used to mark out the city boundr, which took the form of a Macedonian mantle. While Alexander was pleasing himself with the projaot, a oload ot birds alighted and devoured the flonr. Alexander, whose whole life neema to have been infl îenced by omens, was much troubled thpreat, until the aagnrs dispelled hia doubts by observing that it was a sign that the oity should feed many nations. And so it has. Bnt it was not only a oity that Alexander founded on these mystio shores ; it was not merely a way side caravanserai for Asia and Africa. The foundations that he laid were thoie of a oivilization which, born in the shade of the Atoropolis'of Athens, was destined to dominate the world. Hellenio culture had been in ocoo pation of the Nile Valley long before the bombardment of Alexondri*, and the landing of oar troops. Neo Platonics disappeared with the birbirouB destruction of the Library of Alexandria, whose prioeless volumes warmed the publio bitlis ot the victorious Saracen, bat the keen witted traier sucoesded to the philosopher, and the Orthodox Greek Chnroh has keep alight the saored flros of Hellenism, so that to-day, a3 under the Ptolemies, the Greek element prevails, and nowhere in Egypt is it more conspioaons than in this city, the see o( an Orthodox Patriarch.

The appeal I make to Hellenes is also an appoal to all thise nations who have benefited by Gresk civilization. They, no less than the Greeks, owe Alexander an everlasting tribute. No other potentate of pre Christian times did so mioh for spreading civilisation, and combating the Orientalism which then threatened the world. His ex- ploits marked a critical epooh in the world's history, an ep^ch foretold in ths visions of Daniel. That, chronologically, was important, bat not all. What really Alexander accomplished, and by divine mandate, was the introduction into the apathetic Eastern world of that period of that splendid instrument of thought, the Greek language, which was to prepare the world's intelleot for that marvol of the ages—the coming of Ch-ist.

A suggestion made is to ereot an Imposing statoe of the warrior upon the breakwater, facing the ses, the right baud resting on his sword, and his left submitting to tin world the oity ut Alexandria. Peatelioas would supply excellent material for such a monnaient, bâtit is to the qaarriss of patriotism to which one must first refer. Already one generous German has ooutribited L E. 500 towards the sotnme-, bat to be realised considerable fuads are neoessary. and it is to be hoped that the natious of the world whose ships have found shelter in the harbour since time immemorial will respond goneronsly to the appeal.—Your?, eto.,
L. M.
Balke'ey, January 10.

div.head: MR. DICEY AND THE "TIMES"
div.p: To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette

Sir,—Mr. Dicey's article in the "Empire Review," part of which you reproduce to-day, has reopened some of the questions raised by the article published by the "Times" of November 27. Into the question of the relations between H.H. the Khedive and the Egyptian Nationalists I do not propose to enter. The " Times' " correspondent gives one opinion, Mr. Dicey another, and the editor of the "Egyptian Morning News" gives his opinion that Mr Dicey (the veteran journalist, etc, etc.) has let the 'Times' correspondent off too lightly. Certainly, if I am allowed to draw inferences from the signed leaders that appear in the "Morning News," Mr. Graves has replaced "Ras" MacGillivray in "Bernie's" bad books. Such are the penalties of journalism ! Meantime I note that the veteran journalist, in an article appearing in the "Empire Review," maintains that the great majority of grades and decorations are given "by the intermediary of the British Agenoy" to officials ! Can Mr. Dicey give any figures to support a contention which has not been borne out by a single oi e of the lists of recipients which have appeared in the official journal for years past ? Or is this a sign that even veteran journalists are fallible, witness the recent confusion of Mustapha Pasha Kamel with Mustapha Pasha Kamel El Gamrawi and the statement that Mr. Dunlop had never had any educational experience. I fear that here again 'good Homer nods."

div.head: THE ENGLISH IN EGYPT
div.p: To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette."

Si', —In one of the last number# of the "Egyptian Gazette" I read an interesting artiole dealing with the snbjeot of the British Administra, tion in Egypt The writer states that Englishmen- who are aware of the general improvements effected in Egypt since the date it was pet under the British control, wonder how it is possible that after so many manifest benefits which Egypt and its inhabitants derived from E ig'aud, there should be an anti-Euglish feeling among the Egyptian and others, and he attributes that to base ingratitude.

I have lived for many years in a British oolony, and in my capacity as a Government official I had the opportunity of watching olosely the British administrative maohine and the people living onder that administration, and my impressions I respectfully give herein to the pnblio odnsideiation for as much as they are worth.

British role as a principle is comparatively perfect and whan applied by competent persons is Buoh as would leave nothing désirable.' The remits of it are manifestly good, and to whatever British oolony one looks be can easily understand that the prosperity of the country is mostly due to British role.- All people living andor the British Flag unanimously admit that the Government is good in every respect, as justice is generally given to those who deserve it, life and estate security are suoh as one cm expect, religions are nevor interfered with, the press is free ; bat quite extraordinarily, while admitting and believing, all that, thsy in the meantime have a hatred and detestation for Euglisb rule, and they oheri.;h a feeling of reveage towards Eiglan^, which feeling they are only too happy and ready to show as soon as a suitable opportunity presents itself.

The reason of this is partly the social life of the Englishmen and the latter's behavionr towards every person who is not English, lo anoient times the Hellenes had a selfiih principle :— "He who is not Hellene is barbarous," and this maxim of the ol ien times, although publicly disapproved, is selfishly appropriated by the Englishmen of nowadays, and its application partly in offisial life and wholly in social life is most severe.

them, do not like to conrider that their iffioial life is perfect, bat they throw them away from their true, esteem and love. The best of servants is he who obeys his master obeerfully and because be loves and eale?ms him, not because he is afraid of him or is compelled to do it. With the former matters go smoothly and there is no need to use compulsion,, while with the other there is always disorder, loes of .time, and companion has t) be need. If Englishmen find they are obeyed and they see any hing they want done, and that the natives show them every respeot, I am snre most of them feel that snob respect is only affeoted, and under it there is hidden a deep sentiment of contempt, hatred, and revenge, the existence of which it is in the interests of the British
polite, intelligent, ooorteon», agreeable, good- heartod like they, and beoaase they havo be >u accustomed to 1 ok at the natives with contenait and consider sud treat them like servants.

Tbe reasons assigned for this proud conduct arc many, and I will only be able to enumerate a few. They have a bad conception of policy and they »hink that by keeping aloof from 'he nativos they oan ruh be'ter and remain impartial. This cannot be oorreot, foV I h.ve always known Englishmen to be of strong charaoter and they never admit that they oan be madd partial. They think that the natives ill not know h >w to behave and speak in their.salons, which of course is wrong as mahy of the natives are very ag'teable and interesting in society.

It might be sui 1 that Englishmen do as- s ciate with the natives, allud.ing ol coarse to some coarteons words exchanged as an introduction to bnMues*. or some tea parties or "at-homes" and the like, but this is not what is meant as surely each associations are never "intime" and every precaution, isoarefully taken by the Englishmen not to m .ke them suob, and this is exactly what harts the feelings of the natives.

There might of course be other reasons which may be the oaoie of this behavioar of the Englishmen, but whatever stfoh re»*on be it see as in the interes's of the British nation that it should be d;solosed and the right or w*ong of it deoided upon by the pnblio oj inion.
Cairo, January 9.

div.head: OUR SERVANTS.
div.p: To the Editor of the ' Egyptian Gazette."

Dear Sir,—I am, glad to see that you have opened your powerful columns to a disoossion of the servant question in Bgypt. It is no exaggerations say that the Berberi servant spoils domestio life for the European resident in Egypt. Ho never 'does an honest day's work, he receives eaormoas wages, he is cheeky to the. mistress when the master is away, and if in any way offeuded he walks out of the house, and there is no redress.

I oan assure "An Old Resident" that higher olass officials suffer very much more severely from this inoonvenience than he appears to imagine. The reasons for the high wages and impndence are not far to seek. The former are caused by the fact that money is easily made and easily spent nowadays in Egypt by business men, and the latter by the supply not baing equal to the demand. There are not enough respeotable men to go round.

The best way to get over this difinalty would be for an aganoy to be slatted for the employment of Guaaesa servants, the type of men who Berve as stewards in the P. & 0. ships. There are already a few in the country and they give satisfaction. If a certain nom bar of parsons would agree to take a certain nomber of these servante there chon Id be little or no trouble to some enterprising agent in obtaining them from Bombay, where similar agencies already exist.*—Faithfully yours,
Alexandria, Janaary 10. A Suffbrer.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: The first annnal dinner of the King's Royal Rifle Corps will be held on the 28th Febiuary in London, under the presidency of Sir Red- vers Bailer, Colonel Commandant of the Corps.

The 3rd Battalion K.R.R.C. is preparing a strong draft to join the 2nd Battalion at Jubbulpore; and it will leave Aldershot about the 9th insb., under the command of Captain J. A. D. Laughorne, Royal Garrison Artillery* The draft numbers 86 of all ranks.

Major Henry R. Beddaes, Royal Dahlia Pasiliers, has gone on retired pay. Majot Beddoes served in the Royal Fusiliers from Ocober, 18S6, was engaged in the Burmese Expedition, 1888-89, British Central Afrioa operations, D-96-97, Northern Nigeria, 1899-04, was severely wounded in the Ashanti campaign, and commanded the 2nd Northern Nigeria Regiment^in the Bontiki Expedition, 1902. He stood as a "Rasaellite" candidate at the late General Election for East Antrim, and was beaten by Colonel MoCalmont by a very big majority.

The vaoant maj erity in the R fla Brigade has been filled by the promotion of Captain Visoonnt Hawkeibary, M.V.O., who has been a supernumerary for some time. Lord Hawkesbnry donned the "Green Jaoket" in May, 189ir*cd got his company in Deoember, 1897.

LientenantR.W. Hadow, 1st Battalion Royal Highlanders, has been seleoted foe service with the Egyptian Army, and has been ordered to proceed to Egypt as soon as possible, and report himself to the 8irdar at Cairo. Mr. Hadow joined the Black Watch in May, 1901, and reached the front in time to share in the operations in the Transvaal and Orange River Colony 1901-02 (Q teen's medal with four olasps).

Lieutenant E. 8. Girdwood, 2nd Battalion, Scottish Rifles, who has been seleoted for service with the Egyptian Army, is the senior subaltern of that regiment He got his commission in this R flss in May, 1899, served with the 2nd Battalion in the South African Wkr, including the aotion of Colenso, Vaal Krantz, Spion Kop, Laing's Nek, and the soaeaediog oampiig , including the defjnoe of Fort It*l« and Fort Prospeot (me itioned in despatches, Queen's medal with foor o'asps, King's medal with two olasps).

Iu March next, Colonel C.W. Thompson , D.S.O., will vacate the command of the 7tb Princess Royal's Dragoon Gnardi, Canterbury, on the completion of tbe regulation four yaatt at its hiad. Colonel Thompson has been aaso oiated wi'.h the gallaat old "Bladk Horse'' since January, 1882, whan ho received his first com mission. The same yoar he went throagh th Bgyptian War, and shared in the two aotion- of Kassaesio, the battle of Tel el-Kebir, and that famous ride of a handful of our oavalt] to Cftiro, and the surrender of that placi to them (medal with olasp and Khedive's star). He was promoted oaptain in 1887, maj.. in 1897, and he was promoted to the commatx of the regiment in March, 1903. He serve' with it tbrooghont the South Afrioau War, was pre ent at the operations in the Free State and the Transvaal, including the aotiUns of Johannesburg, Pretori j, and Diamond Hill. the operations cist and west of Pretoria, and commanded the regiment from the end of 1900 to the oiose of the war, throngh tbt harassing work in Orange River Colony, Capc Colony, and ou the Natal borders of Zuloland (mentioned in despatches Q men's medal with f >nr c'a pi, Ring's medal with ol&sps, brevet lieutenant ooloneloy).

The Second Croiser Squadron has been re duoed to four ships by the payingoff of the Can berland and Cornwall into the Home Fleet at Devonport. This is in accordance with tbt cheese paring polioy of the present Goveu - ment. The Seonnd Croiser Squadron, whicl was at the top of the list in gonneiy in 1906 now consiotsof the cruisers Drake (flagship r ( Prinoe Lonit of B&tteoberg, the best shootin; and qui'kest croiser in the navy, Berwid Black Prince, and Duke of Edinburgh.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY.
JUNIOR CHAMPIONSHIP POLO TOURNAMENT.
div.p: The first ties of this tourn*mso4wwe played ys ter day, the sid« competing being as f jliows : .Tigers Coldstream Guards II. Capt Sterliog, L Sir Walter ôarttelot, I. Mr. M&cQillivray, II. M'. Jarvis .Smith,. II. Mr. Jenkioson, III. Capt Darrell, III.
Mr. J. Reid, Book. Major Pereira, Back.

From the throw-in the Coldstream Gaards 'got away," nearly scoring a goal, Mr. Reid, on the well-known old pony "Betteferon," missing his back hander. With the "bit oat" Mr. Jenki neon, for the Tigers, oamçawayat a great pace, anl from a good ran op the greand missed the goel.j- he -was, however, more saooeasful with hi# next attempt Meeting the ball from the hit out, he sooted the first goal for the Tigers.

The Coldstream Gaards then made f determined attack, in which Capt. Darrell was conspioaons. This last-named player, who is an oaraman of greet renowo, bite with great power, and will, we prediot, soon beoome a good player.

list.item: Cbakker. Pity was keen and fast, the Guards being mostly on tbe defensive.
Chukker. Mr. MaoGillivray^ who, in spited an injared arm, played a strong game throughout, aoored a olever goal for his side, and from the throw-io yet another was added.

Chukker. Mr. Jenkinson, who was the best player oc the ground, soored two goals in quiok soooession. The Gaards, however, who may be congratnlated on the plooky uphill fight they made, were not to be denied, soor- iug their one and only goaL..io^hii period. Final Soore : Tigers, 5 ; C. Gnards, 1.

div.p: For the "Tigers," Mr. Jeukinson wae playing a great game. Capt. Darrell and Major Pereira, for the Gaards, showed grand pluck, aniwoald not own defeat outil the bell was "rang," Sir William Barttelot and Mr. Jervis Smith were evidently a good deal handicapped with "green" ponies.

Many of the fair sex were watohing and showed keen interest in the. game. The- Innis. Yilliog Dragoons Band played a ohoioo seleotion ot maaio, and addei considerably to the eejoy- meut of the afternoon.
The next tie# will be played on Saturday.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:-
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 4 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers, of the P.&O. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageriea Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; hero there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Donino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange ; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza :

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO, may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of lake Maggiore has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse

A delightful exeption from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad and from Stansstad it is about 1 hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titlis, is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand; extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santis to the Matterhorn.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND.-INTERLAKEN a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.
